dialogues.text: Adam skims through a catalogue of clothing intended for cancer patients until he notices HENRY (50), a very small sitting in a wheel chair which is attached to a respirato Despite the fact that every breath Henry takes looks like might kill him, he barks derogatory statements at the wal Adam looks on in terror. The genial MITCH(85) notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Henry. 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's always like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that going to happen to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best not worry about these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALAN (84), the contentious old man sitting next to Mitch chimes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want a hit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam looks down to see that Alan is holding a ONE HITTER of weed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes it all a little easier to handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if someone sees us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be such an old man. Look at this place, it's like Death Row in here, they don't give a shit what we do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam reluctantly takes a hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lucky. Life only gets worse anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan, stop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't listen to him, he's just messing with you. 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all downhill from here. Trust me. First your hair's going to fall out, then your balls will shrink. You'll marry a woman, or man, who'll suck every penny out of your savings and then leave you for a fitness instructor in a teal Miata. Then, to top it all off, your kids will one day stop talking to you because their therapist, who you pay for, tells them you're the reason they're so fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to excuse Alan here, he's going through a rough time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just being realistic. You want some advice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't end up a victim like the rest of `em. Life sucks, the earlier you accept it, the better off you'll be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to tell you, I was really nervous about this whole cancer thing, and then I met you guys, and boy do I feel better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan and Mitch laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like this kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Alan Liebowitz: stage 4 lymphoma. Pleased to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch Horowitz, metastatic prostate cancer. 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam Schwartz, schwannoma neurofibrosarcomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is that?...Sounds like the greek dish I had for lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam is beginning to feel the effects of the weed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... man this pot is really strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medicinal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good shit eh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam stares off into space. He's really high, almost like he's tripping. The walls start spinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam is standing on line for a Roller Coaster. He gets to front of the line when the CARNIE stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey you! What do you think you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything Adam says is in German and subtitled in Englis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read the sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Carnies points to a sign that reads "No Cancer."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Carnie points out Adam's T-shirt, it reads "I'M WITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam turns around to see a GIANT BALD FAT MAN eating cott candy, his shirt reads "CANCER".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam tries to run away, but he's attached to the Giant Fa Bald Guy via an umbilical cord. The Giant Fat Bald Guy reaches out, picks Adam up, and swallows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam jolts out of bed. His clothes are drenched in sweat. looks down to see Rachel sleeping peacefully next to him. quickly gets out of bed and runs into the bathroom. And b the sound of it, throws up. A lot. Rachel mutters somethi incoherent and then sprawls out, consuming the entire bed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam looks worn and exhausted from the chemo. He's never worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how do you feel after your first treatment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like I was just gang raped by the Buena Vista Social Club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is everything with you going to be a joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious. Have you heard their horn section?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam, you have a responsibility to your mind and body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just injected with three pints of kryptonite. Can we please hold off on the new agey stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't just sit there and ignore what's happening to you...You need to stop bottling everything up. 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I need is for people to stop telling me what I need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you considered that this cancer is nature's way of telling you to change the way you live your life? (off Adam's look) ...There's an old saying - you can't change the wind, but you can adjust the sails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They teach you that in medical school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie's patience is waning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you don't like to talk about your feelings, but you have to learn to find an outlet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An outlet for what? I have cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how is your body ever going to fight the stress of that cancer if you can't even handle your own emotions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam snaps, rasing his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well excuse me. You'll have to forgive me for not having a firm handle on my emotions at this particular juncture of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie's a little shaken by Adam's outburst. She stays fir

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam knows he went too far. Plus, that little outburst li a little wight off his shoulders, and he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I know you're only trying to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all too much for me. I don't know what to do. Just tell me what to do and I'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie looks at Adam, is he being for real? She's skeptica

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to do some homework. Here's a list of books on mind-body therapy. They should help you get started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie hands Adam a sheet of paper with a list of books scribbled on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Seth browse through shelves of books. Seth is reading the author's bio from one of the books on Katie's list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Franz Schlegel is an American `medical intuitive' and `mystic psychiatrist'. Schlegel's teachings are widely recognized as a global spiritual awakening that is transcending individual and collective human consciousness"... You're actually going to read this shit? This guy is a fucking tool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth ditches the New Age book and picks up one on Mardi G

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go to Mardi Gras!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would we go to Mardi Gras?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's Mardi Gras man. It's like a giant orgy of the sexiest women you can imagine all throwing themselves at you, screaming to be fucked. It's a fuck fest. 61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting chlamydia just listening to you talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to go see the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't my bachelor party we're planning here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam you can not let your cancer go to waste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam takes the book from Seth's hands and puts it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From across the store, Seth notices, CLAIRE (30), an attractive employee stacking books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well if you're not going to take advantage of your cancer, then I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth yanks the list of books from Adam and crosses to Cla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, how can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking to buy a few books -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth hands Claire the list of book titles. She reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are these for...I'm sorry it's none of my business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No that's okay. They're for my best friend, Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth nods towards Adam across the room. 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's pretty sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire shoots Adam a look - the way one looks at a dying puppy. Adam looks on in confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Cancer, not cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's been really hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's bad isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I just wish it was me instead of him...to relieve some of the burden, you know? I just...I just want to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Seth exit the bookstore. They pass Claire who gi Seth a big smile followed by the "call me" motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What just happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what happened. Cancer happened, and you need to get on the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Seth smoke a joint as they watch "Planet Earth" brand new 50" flat screen TV. There are a dozen oversized boxes marked "Rachel" scattered throughout the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel yells from the bedroom. 63.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Adam do you know where the dog leash is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to the park again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel enters the room with the dog cradled in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the third time today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He likes running around with the other dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can barely make it to the door without shitting himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel finds the leash and then smells the joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you smoking weed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when do you smoke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's medicinal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel's shocked, this is way out of character for Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a prescription for medicinal marijuana?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night blindness. Rods and cones are off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel rolls her eyes. Seth is ridiculous. Then she notic the new flat screen TV on the wall and just like that, he demeanor switches. She looks pissed. 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did that TV come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The store. (off Rachel's furious

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's medicinal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we already agreed that my painting was going there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to reason) Why can't we put up both?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to put my painting next to a television?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art needs to breathe Adam!...Do whatever you want. I'm taking your dog to the park!...And open a window. This isn't a dorm room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel walks to the door, scoops the dog up in one arm an bag of garbage in the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out to Rachel) Love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door slams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it, they spend all day at the dog park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Maybe she'll move there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you not talk about her like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth nearly chokes as he inhales. 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you joking? Do you see the way she treats you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got some kind of creative block...It's her process.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have cancer for fuck's sake! If I was your girlfriend, I'd be baking you cookies and blowing you every thirty minutes. Instead, she's yelling at you over some fucking painting. Her art sucks. You don't want to put that on your wall. It looks like someone threw up a shrimp cocktail and then used it to spackle the Berlin Wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going through a rough patch. That's what happens in relationships.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit. She's fucking you in the ass Adam. This is the one time in your life you can do whatever you want. If you want to smoke weed, then smoke. You want a 50 inch flat screen TV, then get the fucking TV! And if you want to go to Mardi Gras, then LET'S GO TO MARDI GRAS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to Mardi Gras.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth takes a hit from the joint and hands it back to Adam

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he exhales) You're totally missing my point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam sits in Katie's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been reading your books, and you know it actually makes sense...Some of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna lie, I don't really get the "Dark Night of the Soul" stuff. But I get it, years of anxiety have taken over my body. I'm blocked...emotionally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam! This is fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam is slightly taken aback by Katie's response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know if you're interested, there are some more advanced forms of therapy that I think could be really useful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, if you think it'll help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Seth are seated in a semi-circle with a half doz middle aged men and women. At the front of the group is t LAUGHTER THERAPIST (50) - a short man with a long greying pony tail and a thick beard. All eyes are closed except f Seth and Adam's. Adam's hair is noticeably thin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning class. Before we begin I'd like to introduce Adam and Seth, our two newest giggle gurus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class laughs. Adam and Seth look around paranoid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly to Adam) What are they laughing at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly to Seth) Just go with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth and Adam laugh along with the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Adam and Seth) Now what you'll soon discover is the true miracle and gift of laughter.

dialogues.speaker: LAUGHTER THERAPIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Learning to laugh at ourselves and others through non- judgemental means is far more effective than any prescription drug, or, rehabilitation center. You see, when we laugh, our bodies release endorphins that not only support the immune system, but also release deeply stored emotional pain, and give us a fresh new outlook on life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Laugh Therapist opens his eyes and stares intensely a Adam and then Seth.

dialogues.speaker: LAUGHTER THERAPIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We don't tell jokes here, we tell the truth - and we laugh at that truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Laughter Therapist closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LAUGHTER THERAPIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So let us share. Adam, why don't you tell us what brings you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam looks around in fear of saying the wrong thing.

dialogues.speaker: LAUGHTER THERAPIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're all friends here in the Laughter Pagoda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, ah, have cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire class laughs hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah cancer yes. Yes. Laugh. Everyone. Beverly, share -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday, I confiscated my son's pornography collection and then used it to masturbate 6 times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, share,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife told me she's a lesbian. And then left me for my sister. 68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I owe two men eight grand by Friday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My best friend is a giant pussy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My best friend's favorite band is Abba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone laughs except for Seth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abba! Wonderful. I love it. Seth laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME LAPSE: Adam stares at himself in the mirror. His hea slowly deteriorates. Hair begins to fall out. His face th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam, Alan and Mitch sit in the corridor of the Cancer Wa Adam is wearing a ski hat to cover his balding head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real. 69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal an INSANELY HOT WOMAN with gi breasts in a hospital gown walk by the three men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're both wrong. I think I know real when I see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hot woman scratches her head, revealing that she's wearing a WIG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan hands Adam and Mitch each a five dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch notices Adam watching one of the OTHER PATIENT's sitting and laughing with HIS WIFE. There's a longing in Adam's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come we've never met Rachel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. What the fuck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's been really stressed lately,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam looks around at all the sick people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I brought her here, she'd probably freak out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smart man. Save yourself the headache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't listen to him Adam. It's important to be with your loved ones in times like these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit. Women are nothing but trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're selfish animals who only add to the misery in your life. You want to talk about a cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me Adam, I've been married 40 years and it's my Margaret who keeps me going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch pulls out his wallet. He holds out a picture of his wife MARGARET (80).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's my reason to live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's precious Mitch, I almost want to wrap it up and tie a little bow around it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly, I don't give a shit. You can do whatever you want. It's your life. All I know is that I'm not going to spend my last days on this miserable planet pining over a woman. The day my wife left me was the best day of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam let's this soak in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam's on his cell phone pacing in front of the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey, it's Rachel. I must be doing something really important. I'll give you a call when I'm done...yay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey it's me, just checking to see if you're on your way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam paces impatiently. He calls Rachel again, it goes straight to voice mail. 71.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey, it's Rachel. I must be doing something really important. I'll give you a call when I'm done...yay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me again. Just checking to see where you are. In case you're looking for me I'm now on the other side of the parking lot. Call me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Katie walks to her car, she sees Adam pacing and mumbl to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just waiting for Rachel to pick me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is she coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's six thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must be stuck in traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam is seated in the front seat as Katie drives. The car filthy - it's littered with papers, magazines, food wrapp etc. Katie's body is pressed all the way up against the steering wheel with her eyes fixed on the road. 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about the mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam picks up a copy of "Organizing Your Way to Success," which is lying on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should ask for a refund.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know. What can I say? I'm not good at getting rid of things. I get easily attached.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Changing the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you have a license?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I actually failed my test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, I thought you can re-take the test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh. Let's just say, that the state of California felt it was best I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie stares at Adam in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do? 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kind of backed my mom's car down an embankment...Into the Balboa cactus garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The garden with all the endangered plants?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't want to tow it out in fear of destroying more of the vegetation, so they had to use a giant crane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie lets out a tiny chuckle, but quickly contains herse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. That's terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unable to hold back, Katie continues laughing. This is th first time we've seen Katie let go of her rigid nature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie looks at Adam nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why what's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just stop the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie stops the car. Adam grabs a handful of Katie's garb and gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't handle all this mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam tosses the garbage in a dumpster and comes back to t car for more. Katie starts laughing, she can't believe Ad is cleaning her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, no, not that, that's my dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam leaves Katie's dinner and throws out the rest of the garbage. He gets back in the car and takes a deep breath. 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Katie arrive at Adam's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the ride...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam looks at his house. The lights are out. He's really in the mood to be alone. He looks back at Katie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to come in. For a beverage? Or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It probably wouldn't be very professional of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, I'll let you analyze my Id.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie is hesitant, but she also feels in a strange way th Adam is more than a patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, okay. But I can't stay long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Katie sit on the couch playing an ultra-violent video game. Katie is destroying Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know you are terrible at this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam is totally lost. He has zero sense of how to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never played before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your Playstation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't mean I play it. Games these days today are so complicated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's too many buttons. I can't keep track of what does what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you'd prefer something a little more simple. Maybe a nice game of Connect Four or Bingo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has a sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie's face lights up. She's proud of herself for that o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duck Hunt, now that was a game. You know why? One button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm kidding. My dad and I used to have Duck Hunt tournaments. He was actually really good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until he had his stroke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must have been hard, seeing him lose his cognitive skills like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the most emotionally honest we've ever seen Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well the funny thing is that the stroke actually made him a better player, he just lost interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie feels for Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never talked about your dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well whose fault is that? Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two continue to play. Adam wildly pushes every button Katie's character pins Adam's character and repeatedly sl his head into the ground. 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Game over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie pats Adam on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rematch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam holds out a tray of wheat grass as he prepares to bl wheat grass shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever had this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but it's supposed to be really good for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it smells like my grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You complain a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't met my mother. It's a miracle I do anything but complain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I try not to look at the world like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world would be a boring place if we didn't complain. Come on. There's got to be something. One thing, just one thing, that drives you nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really don't like it when people at work finish all the coffee and don't refill the pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's infuriating right? 77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't say infuriating. It's just not good work place etiquette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam is far more excited by this revelation. He hands Kat shot of wheat grass and takes one last sniff of the awful smelling drink. He raises his glass to make a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To complaining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam downs the drink and cringes at the taste. Katie foll and in total disgust, she spits her wheat grass all over Adam's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god, that's disgusting. I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie grabs a towel as Adam stands speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on. I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam keeps his eyes closed as Katie wipes his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it all gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time, Katie notices how cute Adam is. Adam opens his eyes to catch Katie staring at him. They lock e for a moment. Uncomfortable, Adam averts his look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Rachel walks through the front door.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Adam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feeling a little foolish, Katie motions to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should probably be going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel enters the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally. Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope I'm not interrupting. 78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, this is Dr. McRae, my therapist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your therapist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, call me Katie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Katie. What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drove me home. Ring a bell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh. Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much for doing that. Life's been a little crazy lately, which I'm sure Adam has told you all about. I love those shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awkward silence. The tension is thick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to go. I'll see you at our next session Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was at the gallery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were supposed to pick me up. 8 hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I'm sorry. I totally spaced. With the opening only three months away my head's just all over the place. (off Adam's look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look at me like that. You know this is a hard time for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. Let me go back and talk to the doctor - see if maybe they can diagnose me with something that better suits your needs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not just some car service here to shuttle you around!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my house isn't a summer camp. You can't just come and go as you please and not take some responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is it that I'm not taking responsibility for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This. Us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't handle this! You make it sound like I'm your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I thought the other day? That I might actually die without ever having sex again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if your cancer isn't turning me on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think this is easy for me seeing you sick like this? The past few months have been hard on me too. It's not always about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam tenderly wraps his arms around Rachel. 80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you so good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're my Yam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel stares at Adam as he sleeps next to her in bed. Sh slowly moves her index finger along Adam's arm and then seductively kisses his neck. Adam firmly grabs hold of Ra and the two begin to go through the motions. Clothes come off. Adam gets on top of Rachel...And then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam rolls over onto his back. He and Rachel lay silent - neither making contact with the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam sits down next to Mitch, but notices there's no Alan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Alan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speechless, Mitch looks up at Adam and slowly shakes his head. Tears roll down Mitch's cheek. Adam's face goes whi 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Mitch stand next to the RABBI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tombstone reads "ALAN LIEBOWITZ (1923-2007) FINALLY."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA TILTS up to the sky, and then DOWN to reveal:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A healthy Adam is surrounded by dozens of energetic elder people who are swimming, playing bocci ball, shuffle boar bridge, etc. Adam looks on in confusion as an OLD MAN wea an official looking badge drives by on a golf cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man stops his cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The After Life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Heaven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man scratches his balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty great huh? They've even got a frozen yogurt machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man points to a long line of excited seniors awai their turn at a massive Frozen Yogurt Sundae Bar. A sign front reads "WAIT: 45 MINUTES".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are lines in Heaven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's worth it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: End Dream. 82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam jumps from bed in cold sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam is seated in the Rabbi's office, he looks despondent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you want to know what's going to happen when you die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's a fair question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair yes, but impossible for me to answer. Our deaths, like our lives, have meaning and are all part of God's plan. How should I know what God has planned for you. Maybe if you came to service once in a while...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well am I going to go to Heaven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I want to just die? That's it. No Heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's like buying a ticket for a cruise and then not going. The Afterlife is where the fun begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can being stuck in some nonexistent void with my grandparents be fun. I spent my entire life trying to get away from my family, now I'm going to have to spend an eternity with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam, you can not look at death as a curse. Even in death we are all still part of God. Life on Earth is just the beginning. 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's not what I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oy. Then find another religion. I don't make the rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam is lying on the couch staring at the ceiling. There total silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're being awfully quiet today. Is everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to die aren't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam sits up and looks at Katie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not getting any better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say that, you're doing so well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know that they found a Quasar 7 billion light years away? 7 billion light years! It's more than 3 billion years older than our planet, and we're just seeing it now; and you think I'm going to live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cancer is an epidemic! It killed Alan, it's going to kill me, and it's going to kill millions more after me. There's nothing anybody can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is really good Adam. Let it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do this anymore. It doesn't matter. None of it. I'm going to die and with nothing to show for my life. 100 years from now my legacy be will be that of just another person dead of cancer. That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This helplessness you're feeling is normal. These emotions you're holding onto are what make you human. But it doesn't mean you can just stop living your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at how you've grown over the past few months, you can't just throw it all away...Talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're only trying to help, but this isn't working for me anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam leaves. Katie is left feeling as though she failed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam lies on the bed of an MRI machine. His body is slowl drawn into the enclosed body scanner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME LAPSE: Adam's stares at himself in the mirror. His health deteriorates even more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking at himself in the mirror, Adam takes note of his hollow cheeks and worn eyes. He looks awful, like an old There isn't any youth left. He's not getting any better, he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noticing a few renegade hairs sticking up, Adam pulls out lint brush and combs his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel enters and steps up on the scale. She examines her in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a new lint brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll pick one up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I have a doctor's appointment next Thursday...The big one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel continues to examines her waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I getting fat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam stares at Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you listening to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you'll take me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel leaves. In frustration Adam weakly picks up the sc and throws it against the wall, smashing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam sits alone in his empty house. It's a mess. He looks unhinged. 86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slowly pulls a hit from a joint as he watches Matlock his flat screen TV, which has been moved to the floor to room for Rachel's painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam flips the channel to Martha Stewart, then to I Love Lucy, then to General Hospital, then to Body Building on ESPN. He turns the TV off. He's bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam crosses to the answering machine. It reads "10 Messages." He presses play. All the messages are from his mother. He hits delete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam reads through a stack of unopened letters. He comes across a postcard from the Museum advertising "Mountain D Presents: The Origins of Man".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: the "Mountain Dew Presents: The Origins of Man" poster in the Museum's main entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam enters the museum and walks up to the sign. People s and stare, stunned by Adam's gaunt appearance - like a gh haunting the grounds. Adam carries a wide smile, he's overcome with a sense of nostalgia for his old job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and Adam sit in Phil's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, look at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to come back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to come back? Here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so crazy about that? 87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could be anywhere right now, and this is that place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure that's a good idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is treading a fine line...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Given...your current health?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said I look great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah for a guy with cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam looks dejected. Phil feels bad, he went too far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, what the hell? I'd love to have you back. Let's be honest this place is falling apart without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're really okay? I mean, the cancer, is-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh it's really good. We've come to an understanding. It takes whatever it wants and depletes me of my every will to live, and I let it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil, second-guessing his decision-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth leads a tour of FOREIGN TOURISTS through the museum. speaks as he did earlier - like a game show host. 88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you look over on your left you'll see our newest exhibit "The Last Days Pompeii." Buried in 79 AD by the catastrophic eruption of Mt. Vesuvius, Pompeii remained hidden and forgotten until 1748 when archeologists began to excavate the site. Here we see exquisitely preserved objects that offer a glimpse into the day-to-day life of this ancient city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth comes upon Adam who is working closely on a diorama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This here is Adam, one of our curators. Adam do you want to tell us what you're working on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gladly. This here is a depiction of what Pompeii's final 19 hours probably looked like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam's exhibit is a highly morbid depiction of Pompeii's final hours. The scene is total chaos. Ash flies through air. Hot molten lava engulfs the town. Miniature men, wom and children run through the streets in horror. People ar sacrificing whatever they can for the Gods. There's a wil orgy in the streets. And a giant TYRANNOSAURS REX model devours a villager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to Pliny the Younger - "You could hear women lamenting, children crying, men shouting. There were some so afraid of death that they prayed for death. Many raised their hands to the gods, and even more believed that there were no gods any longer, and that this was one unending night for the world."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tourists take pictures. In shock, Seth quickly shuttl the group away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok. Moving along we see the beautiful watercolor paintings of John James Audobon. 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth looks back at Adam like he's lost his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of someone vomiting can be heard booming from t men's bathroom. A crowd of Museum guests walk past in hor They look at each other in fear. The toilet flushes. Adam walks out. Everyone stares. Adam smiles in embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be in Pompeii if anyone needs me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam walks back to the Pompeii exhibit. Phil approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feeling okay? You don't look so good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be worse. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil notices the Pompeii exhibit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil feels terrible about what he's going to say next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen Adam...I don't know how to say this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil places a comforting hand on Adam's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry...I get it. You're a good guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come back when you're better. You know you'll always have a home here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Distraught, Adam walks down the Hall of Evolution. Slouch in defeat, he passes the various dioramas depicting human evolution. He begins at MODERN HUMANS and walks backwards time. 90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes to the family of Cro Magnons, then Neanderthal m He stops and looks at Neanderthal - their slumped profile match. He continues down the hall towards the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam walks along the boardwalk. He's surrounded by perfection. The beach. The water. The blue sky. Hundreds beautiful men and women in their 20's and 30's: jogging, biking, surfing, skate boarding, playing volleyball, etc. looks like a raisin among grapes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam stands impatiently on his porch. He looks at his wat and then dials his phone.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey, it's Rachel. I must be doing something really important. I'll give you a call when I'm done...yay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam's face is red with fury. He does his best to hold ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's Adam. Where are you? Maybe you forgot, but my appointment is today. So call me back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enraged, Adam hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam picks up his phone and dials again.

dialogues.speaker: SETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yoooooo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey man, I need you to do me -

dialogues.speaker: SETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Not around. Leave a message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam hangs up and dials again. 91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam holds the phone away from his ear and cringes. A pan regret runs through his body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith, Art and Adam sit in the exam room, each reading th respective magazines - minus Art who is lost somewhere in own world. The tension is thick. Edith looks at her watch shivers. There's a knock at the door. A CUTE NURSE enters

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor wanted me to apologize for running late, he's just in with another patient, but should be out in a few minutes. You guys holding up alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very cold in here. Is there anyway you can turn down the Air Conditioning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately the temperature is controlled by a central thermostat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son has cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, really, if I could I would, but there's nothing I can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam's pissed that his mother has just involved him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles to the Nurse) Don't worry about it. (Scowls at Edith) I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure? I could get you a blanket. 92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really, I'm okay. But thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Cute Nurse) We're fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, but you let me know if you need anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nurse smiles at Adam in sympathy, he smiles back. The Cute Nurse exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Re: the cute nurse) I don't like her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith puts her hand on Adam's forehead. He looks at her h and then picks up a magazine in an attempt to ignore her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith pulls some pills out her fanny pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're like some kind of deranged pusher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what it's like to fear losing your son? No. You don't. When you have children of your own we can discuss it. Now take the pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam puts the pills in his mouth and pretends to swallow. Edith gets up from her chair. As soon as his mother turns away, Adam spits the pills into his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith paces around the room looking at the Doctor's vario degrees on the wall. 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam looks on, annoyed at every step his mother takes. Ed closes in on one of the degrees and puts on her reading glasses for further examination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing, he went to a state college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just worry that you're not getting the best care possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam can't take it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well who needs a doctor when they've got you and your fanny pack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can be a little shit sometimes, you know that? You think I don't know what's best for you? I birthed you. You came out of me. I am your mother, for better or for worse, so accept it. (Re: fanny pack) You don't like this, well I'm sorry. It's my own way of caring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well stop! You're driving me crazy. With the comments and the pills every five minutes. Just stop. I'm not dad. I can take care of myself. 94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith turns away, Adam's words hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I didn't mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith blows her nose as tears rolls down her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you did. I drive you crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam gently puts his hand on Edith's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith turns to Adam helpless and scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all I've got. Look at your father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Art sitting in the chair picking his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've lost him. My true love, gone. I'm never going see him again, at least not in this life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spent his whole life priding himself on his independence, always too stubborn to ask for help and now look at the son of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You happy? You like shitting yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was the greatest thing to ever happen to me. And then I had you, and that was even greater. So if I hover and threaten your independence, so what? You have a mother who loves you more than anything. Is that so awful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Edith share a moment...Dr. Ross storms in the ro carrying a stack of MRI films. He seems rushed. 95.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ROSS
dialogues.text: Sorry to keep you folks waiting. It's been one of those days...car got towed. Wife double parked it.

dialogues.text: Adam and Edith look at Dr Ross with blank stares.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyway I'll cut to the chase. The cancer's not responding to the chemo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Ross places the MRI into the light box.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As you can see...The tumor is continuing to grow here, along the nerve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Edith squint to see what Ross is talking about, see nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do we do?

dialogues.speaker: DR. ROSS
dialogues.text: We need to operate. If we don't remove it soon we risk metastasis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you said surgery was too risky.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ROSS
dialogues.text: We're out of options.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears roll down Edith's cheek. Adam grabs hold of her han

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's going to be okay, right? You're going to fix it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Ross sits, he knows this can't be easy for a mother.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ROSS
dialogues.text: This surgery is no guarantee. The risks are tremendous. And, even if we're able to remove the tumor there's still the chance that Adam, you'll never be able to walk again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam looks at his mother. He firmly grabs hold of her han 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that mean...I can get handicap parking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam's line breaks the tension forcing a slight smile acr Edith's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Distraught and emotionally worn, Adam enters to discover smell of a home cooked meal. He walks through the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands in the doorway of the kitchen staring at Rachel cooking. Rachel turns around. She's in high spirits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel gleefully skips over and gives Adam a sweet kiss o the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smells good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls and I are having a movie night. I somehow got suckered into cooking. (off Adam's look) Don't worry I left you some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam feigns a smile, hiding the pain of his heart breakin a thousand pieces.

dialogues.text: Suddenly Rachel's iPhone VIBRATES. She picks it up, and r her text message. Her face lights up as she reads. She quickly types a reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan. She wants to know what time I'm coming over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (even more suspicious) That's what she just texted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants to know what time you're going over to her house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel puts the phone down on the counter and returns to cooking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, well I'm gonna go lie down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might be out late so don't wait up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam walks to the bedroom. After a beat he moves back to doorway and pops his head around the corner. He quietly watches Rachel cross from the kitchen into the living roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stealthily steps into the kitchen, picks Rachel's iPho off the counter and scrolls through her text messages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck?

dialogues.text: Who's James?

dialogues.text: (re: text message) He wants to know if you're still coming over tonight. Should I tell him you're having a girls night?

dialogues.text: That's funny. It seems as though you've double booked yourself.

dialogues.text: I can't believe you just invaded my privacy like that. 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you just got another text from him. He says "Your skin is the canvas upon which my dreams are painted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me back my phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Hope you're not too sore from this afternoon."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems sweet.

dialogues.text: Adam, it's not what you think.

dialogues.text: Well now how do you know what I'm thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be like that. I didn't do anything wrong.

dialogues.text: You've been cheating on me.

dialogues.text: Adam you're being ridiculous.

dialogues.text: Am I?

dialogues.text: Adam holds up Rachel's phone to display a photo of Rachel naked, covered in red paint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this? And this? And this? There are over a dozen naked photos of you in here. 99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the back door swings open. Oblivious, Seth enter

dialogues.text: Hey guys.

dialogues.text: Bad time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Are you going to break up with me?

dialogues.text: Rachel stares at Adam with her adorable green eyes. She t his hand.

dialogues.text: I want you out my house.

dialogues.text: Seth enters the kitchen and gets in Rachel's face. He sta her down.

dialogues.text: Shame on you.

dialogues.text: Adam and Seth sit on the bow of a docked sail boat. The t have had a lot to drink. Adam is understandably upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your skin is the canvas upon which my dreams are painted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is "dreams" a metaphor, for-

dialogues.text: Seth makes a masturbating motion with his hand.

dialogues.text: That memory is so far from me,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jen giving me a blow job?

dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.text: It's some pretty fucked up shit.

dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.text: I look like Powder.

dialogues.text: What the fuck is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: It makes for a nice incentive.

dialogues.text: I can't date you.

dialogues.text: No I can't.

dialogues.text: Yes, you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I can't.

dialogues.text: Adam I can't date you.

dialogues.text: Here at Linden we're more than just a stopping ground for the deceased. We understand that life is different for everyone, and helping families to see their loved ones off to the hereafter means approaching every funeral and burial with it's own dignity and care...A funeral is a representation of the individuals time spent on earth, so I ask you to reflect on your inevitable interment and think carefully in choosing the service and tomb that best befits you.

dialogues.text: Egh em. Mom. Mom.

dialogues.text: Hmmm.

dialogues.text: Katie sits on the bed next to Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little freaked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small GERMAN ANESTHESIOLOGIST enters. There is somethin incredibly unsettling about her thick accent. 113.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Adam, I am the Anesthesiologist. I will give you shot to make you sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam holds Katie's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be here when I wake up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now relax, this will take a few minutes to feel the effect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Anesthesiologist injects the drugs into Adam's IV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About how long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, you will soon begin the sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what if it doesn't work. How do you know I won't wake in the middle of the surgery? What if I-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like that, Adam's out cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam is face down on the operating table. Two Neurosurgeo Dr. Lamb and DR. HENRY are in mid surgery. Alongside the doctors are Nurse Wong and NURSE SCOTT.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HENRY
dialogues.text: I'm telling you Sir Francis Drake was a Buccaneer.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAMB
dialogues.text: No he was a privateer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought he was a pirate. 114.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAMB
dialogues.text: A pirate works for no one but himself. A privateer has a mandate from a government.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HENRY
dialogues.text: I thought that was a buccaneer.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAMB
dialogues.text: No, a buccaneer is a butcher turned pirate.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HENRY
dialogues.text: Then what's a mercenary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse Wong. Will you Google it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing to the side of the operating table is the group Med Students from earlier. They're still taking notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith, Art and Seth sit impatiently watching the clock. K paces up and down the hall. Hours go by. Time can't seem go by quick enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lamb finds Edith, Katie and Seth in the waiting room.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAMB
dialogues.text: We were successful in the extraction of the tumor. However, as you can imagine, with something of this magnitude...there were some unforeseen complications. The bone corrosion was much greater than initially anticipated. We had to remove part of the hip and pelvis, as well as most of the psoas muscle. We also had to remove a good amount of sheath tissue around the sciatic nerve, the damage to that nerve is considerable, which is going to hinder his ability to walk...He's in stable condition right now, but it's touch and go. 115.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam's in his hospital bed - still asleep from the surger NURSE comes in to change his IV. Adam slowly awakens. He high on morphine. He stares, mesmerized by the nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is the most beautiful dresses. Where did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lamb enters.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAMB
dialogues.text: Adam, I see you're awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAMB
dialogues.text: How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAMB
dialogues.text: That would be the morphine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lamb picks up a handle that's attached to the morphin drip and sticks it in Adam's hand.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want you to push this little button any time you feel pain. It'll trigger the morphine. You think you can do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam moves his hands really slowly in the air -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art and Edith enter the room. Adam reacts like a little k being picked up from pre-school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy! Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My little boy. 116.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember the time you walked in on me masturbating?...That was so awkward...What hotel is this? We need to go on more vacations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie pops her head out from behind Adam's parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're here too! You're soooooo awesome...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie McRae, Katie McRae, Katie McRae. Mic-Rae, Dr. Awesome Mic- Rae...I'd love to make you pancakes sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the most excruciating pain runs through Adam's b causing him to scream in agony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Squeeze the morphine trigger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam squeezes the trigger. The morphine offers immediate relief. He lays back in total bliss, and then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door bell. A hand reaches out. A finger on that hand pu the door bell. The other hand holds a bouquet of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hand belongs to Mitch's wife, MARGARET (80). She stan on the porch of a small beach bungalow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door opens. Margaret looks straight ahead. Noth She then looks down, startled by Adam in a wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hello, I didn't see you, ah down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a glow in Adam's face - he looks younger and more jovial than we've ever seen. 117.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm looking for Adam Schwartz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (face lights up) You're Adam? The way Mitch described you, I always assumed you to be much older. About 50 years older. But, you're just a baby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam blushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so glad you could make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really sorry about Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please come inside. You're just in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam leads Margaret inside, past a dozen oversized boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about the mess. I just moved in...The ocean air is supposed to be good for my recovery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Margaret enter the living room. Everyone's there Edith, Art, Katie and Seth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth and Katie are playing a video game: DUCK HUNT. Edith sets food on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're having a Duck Hunt tournament. You play? 118.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Oh I don't know how to play video games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam holds up the controller - an old Nintendo Gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really easy. One button does everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edith chimes in from across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This food's not going to eat itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone makes their way to the table. Visibly weak, Adam slowly lifts himself out of the wheelchair. He yelps in p Katie starts to help when Seth intervenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth grabs hold of Adam, and with his help, Adam takes a small step and then lowers himself into his seat at the table. Katie places a pillow behind Adam's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam takes Katie's hand, she looks down at him, they exch a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam notices and open window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth ignores Adam as he fills both their plates with food

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. I think there's a red tide or something. My eyes are all itchy. It feels like someone is rubbing sandpaper on my corneas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he serves Adam) Nope. You don't have cancer anymore. No more special treatment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am still in remission. 119.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna spend the rest of your life complaining?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like complaining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FREEZE on the family sitting around the dinner table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the song "That's the Way The World Goes Round" by John Prine as we:
